review_title: Avoid if you value your wellbeing and mental health
pros: Flexible working, although this is no longer that unique as a benefit. Best thing about Bromford is that I did make some good, solid friendships.
cons: I can see that Bromford still receives some pretty good reviews but I've noticed that these tend to be from new colleagues - it's pretty rare you'll see 5 stars from colleagues who've been in their role longer than around 3 years. This will likely be put down to longer serving colleagues 'resisting change' or suchlike. I can assure you that this is not the case for me. When I first joined Bromford I felt a real sense of pride at being part of such an amazing organisation - there was a brilliant culture, people genuinely cared about each other and about Bromford's overall purpose. I felt like I belonged to one big family with shared values and colleagues literally oozing the DNA it prides itself on. Social housing is, by its very nature, a challenging environment so it's absolutely essential that people work together as one team, collaborate, have each others' backs, receive clear direction and communication and always have the end goal in sight at all times. Sadly, this is not the case now. For the last 2 years of my employment, I found almost every single day draining and frustrating. Nobody knows who does what, there are lots of "it's not my job" and the poor neighbourhood coaches are constantly hung out to dry by senior management. As for the DNA - well, it seems that this is now just a pretty set of graphics to impress new starters. Many colleagues still live and breathe the DNA, some still have Bromford running through their veins, but I don't feel that this is modelled by the senior leadership team. Yes, change is absolutely necessary (and important) but the rate of change and knee jerking that goes on at Bromford is just ridiculous and unsustainable. Many of the execs have no social housing experience but that's apparently okay because that's what their directors/heads of are for. Which would be fine ... if only they actually empowered and listened to those people! Perhaps, instead of trying to aspire to be like Virgin, Amazon or some other corporate giant, the focus should be on actually getting the fundamentals right first. Customers are social housing tenants - they don't have a choice which housing association they go to, they get what they're given and all they want is a safe, warm, affordable, home. Of course, there's nothing wrong with aspiring to be the best but I think Bromord is a long way off - tasking neighbourhood coaches to run around their patches before Christmas, frantically fitting Co2 alarms into their customers' houses (because of another team's failings with compliance) does not feel like a Virgin or Amazon way to conduct business. Neither does the way the attempted cyber attack was handled. Yes, from an IT perspective it was dealt with excellently and could have been far worse - but, yet again, those on the front line were left to deal with the fallout of this, with no tools or guidance to help them navigate their way around the many difficult conversations they had to have with their customers. It's always the same - those on the lowest pay get the rawest deals. Those driving around in their Teslas would absolutely not want to have some of the difficult conversations with customers that the neighbourhood coaches are forced to have. Going out shadowing once a year and visiting one or two customers does not cut it. It took me some time to find the confidence and strength to start seriously looking for another job as, aside from everything else, I gradually became deskilled - my role was unrecognisable from the job I originally came to do and there was no consistency in the expectations of the job either. Initially, I protected myself from everything going on by concentrating on my own 'bubble' - I believed that as long as I just focused on my immediate team and ignored the bigger picture I'd manage. But even the bubble developed punctures in the end because, sadly, toxicity and negativity has a way of filtering through. I am just so grateful that fate stepped in with an amazing job opportunity and that I got out before any further damage could be done. So, my advice to anyone thinking of joining Bromford is do so at your own peril. It depends what kind of culture you want to work in, it will suit some people as everyone has different expectations. Of course, it might even turn itself around again one day in the same way it does when there's a new government. Who knows? I do hope so for the sake of those who've stayed loyal.

review_title: It's all about targets and numbers
pros:
1) Flexible working.
2) Good team manager.
cons:
Firstly, this company does not put value on their employees. Staff turn over is high, workloads are unmanageable and pay doesn't match the work expected. They are all about targets, so teams do not work effectively together for the customer and do what's right, they do what will ensure they hit their targets for their specific team and what is "policy".

You can't get anything done, because teams cannot answer a question in an email, they just come back with information completely irrelevant to what you've asked. You'll find your self chasing people everyday, to be lied to when they haven't done anything with it after weeks of chasing.

To add to this, they took my bonus away because I was leaving. Even though i worked many extra FREE hours for the company in evenings, nights and weekends and worked as hard as anyone else in the company. Disgusting attitude and what a way to treat staff, you are just a number here and they'll replace you with some other poor sod.

There is also no accountability and you end up picking up duties other teams should be doing daily, when something is overdue because other teams in the business putting no importance resolving complaints it'll come back on you. 

Overall the experience has left a bitter taste in my mouth in a nutshell.

> Commerial, not really "customer first mentality"
> No accountability for other teams not doing what is asked and agreed.
> Unmanageable workload meaning I had to do many extra hours just to manage my day to day work.
> No value put on employees, only 12 month contracts offered, and the "you are just another number" feeling to it.
> Removal of a bonus which was announced before I left, and if i had handed in my notice 2 days after the 20/6/22 I'd have still got a bonus. Beyond ridiculous.
> Absolutely no time for unskill and additional training without falling behind on workload.
> Can get very clicky, and certain teams are "busy" but spend more times on breaks and "having a laugh" than offer appropriate support.
> Customer contact not able to do the right thing for the customer because of "targets". Again, not customer focused at all.

My own team I can't fault, they are resilient and work hard. Deserve much better.

job_title: Income Management Advisor in Gloucester, England
pros:
- Excellent flexibility - within reason you can choose your own hours, location of work etc.
- Brilliant diversity and inclusion ethos throughout the business. I’ve come in as someone with a hidden disability and have been supported incredibly by both my immediate colleagues and management. 
-Roaming Working - I love that I can choose how to manage my diary and where to work to suit my workload and various tasks. They’ve renovated the Tewkesbury office so it is a real pleasure to go there to work and make use of the facilities. The desk and meeting room booking system is innovative and really helpful. 
- The company regularly looks at how they can make life better for their employees. They are always looking for feedback and despite what other reviews say, I do genuinely believe they use this feedback to shape the culture and benefits of bromford. 
- Personable and approachable senior leaders. They offer a scheme where you can take our a member of our  Leadership 50 team out to shadow you for a day. This is such an excellent scheme and really builds relationships throughout the business. It also shows the senior leaders the type of issues we can face day to day which means they can put things into place to help! 
- Great social opportunities  such as the Bromfest Event held yearly. There’s a real sense of ‘team spirit’ and I’ve met lifelong friends just in the 10 months I’ve been here. 
-good opportunity for progression. You are encouraged to work on projects that help with career progression and there are so many training courses available to help you learn what you need to do to progress.
-fair salary plus £500 per year for health and well-being fund e.g private healthcare or gym membership etc. Good pension. We also get the Rewards portal with lots of discounts for all sorts of places. Not to mention the bonus scheme!! 
- Diverse and useful training opportunities. You are encouraged to take advantage of the excellent training courses and online learning available to you. This covers not only things that would help with your current role but you can also sign up to training and courses to help with career progression. One of the mandatory sessions is for new starters called ‘this is bromford’. During this session you not only get to meet other new starters, but have the opportunity to spend time with the CEO who really takes his time to get to know everyone. 
- Generous holiday allowance with the ability to buy more holiday or sell holiday if you wish.
-Flexible team leaders who let you get the job done without interfering or trying to micro-manage. They are also incredibly supportive and regularly block book times in their diaries to be available to assist you with anything you need help with (e.g difficult visits or general training). 
-The transformation project - although people are always a little frightened of change, the new systems will make life so much easier. The training has been brilliant and the communication around the roll out has been good too.
cons: Car parking at the offices is limited which can sometimes be a struggle.

review_title: Do not believe the marketing hype - avoid at all costs.
job_title: Income Management Advisor in Gloucester, England
pros: For such an awful company, Bromford has the best staff. Many have survived mergers and many years of turmoil and are simply awaiting pensions payday - the majority of new starters leave (very quickly.) The ONLY good thing about Bromford is the amazing people but they are leaving in their droves.
cons:
I accepted a job at Bromford naively believing the sales hype. I loved the idea of the Bromford DNA, was completely sold by how I was told that employees were valued and I embraced the idea that I could really make a difference. Fast forward 14 months and I realised I had been brutally conned. I have never, ever worked for a company with such an unhappy workforce. Where people regularly leave work in tears and are being signed off with stress due to the incompetent management and pressures of the job. It is considered the norm.
The directors swan around in their brand new Tesla’s whilst the staff are told payrise are frozen. I was actually told by my ‘manager’ that ‘we work in social housing for the love of the job.’ Interesting then that the directors enjoy a six figure salary and fat cat bonuses so that ethos does not carry through to the top. Oh, but it’s ok, because when they do cancel your payrise……they send you a KITKAT! For a company that proclaims it values it’s carbon footprint….they posted 2000 individual boxes which contained one KITKAT to its staff. What a degrading, condescending, marketing failure. Here is a novel idea Bromford - pay your staff what they are actually worth and forget the cheap marketing gimmicks which hugely backfired.
Another novel concept from Bromford; manipulate the pandemic and employ intelligent and passionate individuals on a really low salary. Because you can. Then, when the pandemic eases and people start to leave (to companies who actually value them), employ some more….but pay the new staff 25% more than the current ones. Oh, and to add insult to injury, ask the existing staff to train the new staff even though they are paid more! Don’t even think about raising it in a meeting though - our manager frequently rolled her eyeballs and even said she was ‘bored’ with the complaints about salary.
Stress levels within Bromford are ridiculously high - I have worked in many companies and it is immediately apparent how unhappy everyone is. Not just in income but also Lettings, repairs, contact centre, neighbourhood coach’s etc….the list is endless. Apparently the turnover is ‘within expected parameters’ though so that’s absolutely fine then!
Bromford enjoy paying expensive consultants lots of money (they clearly don’t do it for the love of the job unlike the Bromford minions), to produce very pretty charts. These pretty charts are produced at least twice a year and the pretty charts are discussed with the Tesla driving directors. They should show how happy everyone is at work and whether it’s a ‘great place to work.’ Very often the charts aren’t pretty enough for the directors and don’t show the data they would like them to show. And so, they send out yet more carefully scripted surveys to staff (who have so much time to play colour by numbers ) and the expensively paid consultants have another go.
Finally, the DNA. Do not be fooled - it is merely a marketing ploy to make you believe they care. They do not. Phrases such as ‘we benchmark salaries’, ‘we appreciate your feedback and will take that back’, ‘mental well-being is important’ are regularly regurgitated yet are meaningless and soulless. They do NOT want you to embrace the DNA at all. They DO want you to Be Suppressed,  Be Stressed, Be Compliant, Be Happy with Being Underpaid, Undervalued and Treated Like a Replaceable Non Entity by Management with Over Inflated Egos. But - it’s ok - because the particularly bad management won awards on their management skills!
Value your mental health? Turn, very quickly, and run, very quickly, far far away from Bromford. If you are considering a job here, reach out to former employees and - quite simply - don’t do it.

pros:
- Always trying to be as pro-active as possible and stay ahead of the game.
- Not scared of change.
- Management trust you...to make decisions, to challenge the 'norm', to work flexibly, to manage your own work load...they simply just trust you!
- They back your career development; ensuring you go on relevant courses and allowing you to progress and develop in a variety of roles at the company. 
- Great benefits - great pension offerings, holiday entitlement, flexible benefits etc.
- The people!  Colleagues at Bromford are fantastic; always happy to help, insightful, friendly, caring, funny and they all love the company and work very hard to ensure its success.
- Bromford's morals and social purpose - We are all about unlocking our customer's potential and helping them be the best they can; a home is just a springboard; we help them with so much more.
cons: The only one is that sometimes people are so passionate about Bromford and wanting to see it succeed that the lines between work:life balance can become a little blurred!  This is all through the Colleague's own choice though as they are so keen to achieve the very best results for our customers.

review_title: Two years down,  many more to go.
pros: Happy to say that Bromford's approach to it's customers is mirrored with colleagues, we all want the best for each other and that's reflected in relationships that are built on a daily basis.   The phrase Bromford family may sound unusual to those outside of the organisation  but considering how much Bromford is growing it's amazing what a close knit group of colleagues we have and that're all working together to try and help our customers be the best they can be.
cons: There are changes that are required within Bromford, from the ground up, but the desire to change and improve is evident.  We all want to offer an outstanding service to our customers but, at times, this is impaired by our infrastructure. The good news is that we're investing very heavily and there will be some big changes over the next few years which will dramatically improve this.

review_title: 15 years and still loving working for Bromford
pros: The people are fantastic, I have really good working relationships with my managers, colleagues and customers.  The flexibility to manage my day to best suit both myself and customers is brilliant.  I have ownership of my role and take pride in the work I do that benefits the properties, communities and customers in my patch.  The training provided is excellent and the colleague benefits are good.  It is a busy, stimulating and challenging role which I love.
cons: It is important to be able to adapt to change, as an evolving company there are regular changes which do have an impact on how I do my job.  It can be stressful at times being on the front line with customers, but colleague and managers are supportive, however is does help to have a resilient character.

review_title: Bromford taking the lead on health and wellbeing
pros:
Since becoming part of the organisation I have been really impressed with the level of support I have received during a period of change. Bromford have been transparent, go to great lengths to consult people through a range of channels and keep us all fully informed with what's going on in the wider business. I feel fully engaged with my team, line manager and the wider organisation.
I've also been lucky enough to be invested in to become a Mental Health First Aider (along with roughly 70 other colleagues) which gives me the opportunity to support colleagues in crisis, or intervene proactively to prevent a crisis from ever occurring. For me this is a sure sign that I'm with the right employer, a place who cares for its people, invests in our health and wellbeing along with a fantastic programme of colleague development.
cons: Parking can be a bit frustrating at times, but we do have a creative system in place to tackle this.

pros: I've worked at Bromford for just over 15 years in a number of roles at various levels of responsibility. How you are treated and the reality of achieving a work life balance is very dependant on which team you are in and the leader with over all responsibility. It would be naïve to believe that everyone has the same experience. Personally though, I have always had great leaders and the ability to flex my diary to achieve a healthy balance and mean I can do what I need to at home. Colleagues are overall friendly and willing to help each other - I haven't yet found anyone not willing to help if I need them to.
cons: Not everyone gets the same opportunities and its very clear that their are internal politics at play - which don't appear to be managed despite them being well documented and discussed

review_title: I love working for Bromford but recently have had a few sticky moments but Bromford has been great and got me through.

pros: Working from home, free drinks, good flexible benefits
cons:
After far too long wondering who was about to talk about me behind my back, I had to leave. It was just such a strange, but completely false culture. Maybe my expectations were too high having read previous reviews, or there are several people working there who have basically been brain washed!

You are actively encouraged to be nice and lovely to everyone, and most people are nice and lovely, then they go and do something awful behind your back and make your life miserable by gossiping and being generally nasty.

If your face fits, you've got a job for life. It clearly doesn't matter if you can do the job or not, or if you have any experience in it, only that you know someone who likes you and is able to influence that decision.

If you want to be a consultant at Bromford, this is also no problem. In fact, you could leave and come back as a consultant and earn quadruple what you were earning before and no one will bat an eye lid! In fact, bring your friends too, it's no problem there.

If you love a meeting for the sake of a meeting, and making yourself look really busy when actually you've done nothing and not left the house all week, you can easily do it here and no one will mind.
